Result.Abstract: Earlier studies have observed that in moderately-loaded real-time database systems, using an Earliest Deadline policy to schedule tasks results in the fewest missed deadlines. When the real-time system is overloaded, however, an Earliest Deadline schedule performs worse than most other policies. This is due to Earliest Deadline giving the highest priority to transactions that are close to missing their deadlines.
Result.Title: Earliest Deadline Scheduling for Real-Time Database Systems

Result.Title: The EXODUS Extensible DBMS Project: An Overview

Result.Title: Persistence in E Revisited - Implementation Experiences

Result.Abstract: In real-time and goal-oriented database systems, the amount of memory assigned to queries that sort or join large relations may fluctuate due to contention from other higher-priority transactions. This study focuses on techniques that enable external sorts both to reduce their buffer usage when they lose memory, and to effectively utilize any additional buffers that are given to them. We
Result.Title: Memory-Adaptive External Sorting

Result.Abstract: In this paper, we reexamine the results of prior work on methods for computing ad hoc joins. Wedevelop a detailed cost model for predicting join algorithm performance, and we use the model to developcost formulas for the major ad hoc join methods found in the relational database literature. We showthat various pieces of &quot;common wisdom&quot; about join algorithm performance fail
Result.Title: SEEKing the Truth about Ad Hoc Join Costs

Result.Abstract: Work in the area of extensible database management systems addresses two problems with today's (primarily relational) DBMSs. First, current systems are lacking when it comes to meeting the needs of emerging applications such as CAD/CAM, multi-media office systems, image management, statistical data management, and text manipulation. Result.Title: Extensible database management systems

Result.Abstract: The workload of an active DBMS consists of two types of activities: externally generated tasks submitted by users, and rule management tasks caused by the triggering of rules stored in the knowledge component of the system.
